pros: Easy very easy hardly any stress except for the fact that you cannot listen to music
cons: A LOT OF WALKING!! Short breaks because it takes 5 to seven minutes to exit building then depending where you parked can take an additional 3 to 5 minutes! So if your a smoker or have to go to your car BE PREPARED!! A very short break awaits! Also you can have your phone now but you can’t even have one earbud in for music! This is a RIDICULOUS rule! Now I can understand not being able to listen to music if your in the main area of the building or around heavy machinery like moving forklifts working on the conveyor line. IT SHOULD NOT BE ENFORCED IF YOUR PICKING IN THE MODS!! There is not one damn thing that can hurt you there! Well except your dummy self from time to time. They say that if you listen to music it will cause a lot of picking mistakes however if your like me which I think most people are (on this subject) I LEARNED HOW TO WALK AND CHEW GUM AT A VERY YOUNG AGE!! Most people do their job a 100% better because it distracts you from the Madame repetitious part of the job and keeps you from looking at your scanner after every pick checking the clock counting down til your next break! 12 hrs is a very long time working when your uncomfortable! Tip: IF WE CANT LISTEN TO EARBUDS THEN WE SHOULD BE ABLE TO HAVE A SMALL PERSONAL BLUETOOTH SPEAKER!! I tried to do this and some type of manager or something said that I had to turn it off because it was distracting other workers. This was an outright lie

job_title: AWS SOC Analyst in Herndon, VA
pros:
1) Professionalism: I had a good job while looking for other jobs - a luxury, I know: I could afford to be picky. My interview with Amazon Web Services was done at the same time as two other large companies, but Amazon blew me away with their respect for my time, the time they took to get to know me as a candidate, and the quality of questions they asked of me. 

2) In a league of their own: The professionalism I saw during the interview process transferred into the workplace. Everyone I have met as come from a highly qualified place and brings to the table serious skills.

3) Work-life balance: In my first half year, I have had a pretty good work-life balance. Things are picking up, but there is still some balance. I don't mind working the extra time as I am well compensated and this is the big leagues.
cons: Creation out of chaos? It takes a long time to learn who is who at the company, and what org does what. By the time you know the place, it get's reorganized. Other teams may try to do what you do, so you have to be the best. Abstractly, this could yield a very darwinian process where the best teams survive, but organizationally (and from a resources point of view) it seems very inefficient.

pros: It was a good environment to work in most days
cons: I was not able to work my 3 part time shifts in September due to shifts being unavailable every day the shifts were posted as staff were very fast in signing up for open time slots. When I tried to access my employee account, I was not able to sign in. I called the employee resource phone number and was told I had been terminated. I have not ever experienced termination in my lifetime. When I asked why, I was told they would forward my request to HR and I would be notified in 1-3 business days. On the 2nd day, I received a call stating the reason was not working 3 shifts in September. I again stated shifts were not available every time I had tried to sign up. The shifts were posted every day at 6:15 pm and I was signed in at 6:10 pm every day. I was told they would forward my situation to a specialty team member and it would be 7-10 business days before receiving an answer. I received an email 3 business days later stating they were happy to have resolved my issue. However, they did not say how. I called the number again and was told I “was eligible for rehire”, which meant I could re-apply and go through all the steps again, including training. I work a full time job and my options were limited to begin with. However, I managed to work a shift every weekend for 7 months (I took one month off due to the virus pandemic as a precaution). September was the first month I was unable to work the 3 shift minimum. Amazon was sending out reminder emails for the last 3 months regarding working the minimum 3 shifts; however, the emails did not state termination was automatic if you didn’t. And, I still receive emails and text messages of available shifts every day and they couldn’t explain to me why if I was terminated. I enjoyed my shifts working as a shopper at Whole Foods for Amazon. However, the way they handle the HR side leaves a lot to be desired. As a giant in the industry, they should handle the HR side of things differently and with more empathy.
